title: Documentation header broken in Safari
body:
There is some issue in Safari with the header in documentation. I guess that position relative is used wrong. It would work with `position: absolute` and `width: 100%` than there is only the spacing of overlapped content missing. So the content in sidebar needs padding to top.

![lodash documentation 2016-10-21 10-51-39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1907266/19592588/c3b2c4a0-977c-11e6-95ac-c874d188d208.png)

title: .lowercase is not working appropriately
Bug with partialRight/pick/mapValues
Ensure that the passthrough to `Array.prototype.sort` does a stable sort
body:
[closes #1553]

I really wanted to be able to `_.chain()` in a `.sort()` with a custom comparator function, but couldn't stand that it wasn't a stable sort in V8 (and others). This patch does a native sort, but also compares the starting indexes when values are otherwise equal, resulting in a stable sort.

title: added optional "keys" argument for ordered key retrieval from objects
body:
from my wonderings (wandering?) in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1459#issuecomment-253996722

..., on the topic of indeterminate Object ordering, it makes me wonder why:

```
_.values(o, ['3a', 4])
```

Isn't **a thing**...

```
/* @example
 *
 * o = {"3a": 1, "3b": 2, "4": 3, "4a": 4, "5": 5}
 * _.values(o)
 * // [3, 5, 1, 2, 4]
 *
 * _.values(o, ['3a', '3b', '4', '4a', '5'])
 * // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
 *
 * _.values(o, '3a', '3b', '4', '4a', '5')
 * // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
 */
function values(object) {
  return object
    ? (arguments.length > 1)
      ? baseValues(object, flatten(arguments).slice(1))
      : baseValues(object, keys(object))
    : [];
}
```

title: _.values() with arguments
body:
from my wonderings (wandering?) in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1459#issuecomment-253996722

..., on the topic of indeterminate Object ordering, it makes me wonder why:

```
_.values(o, ['3a', 4])
```

Isn't **a thing**...

```
/* @example
 *
 * o = {"3a": 1, "3b": 2, "4": 3, "4a": 4, "5": 5}
 * _.values(o)
 * // [3, 5, 1, 2, 4]
 *
 * _.values(o, ['3a', '3b', '4', '4a', '5'])
 * // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
 *
 * _.values(o, '3a', '3b', '4', '4a', '5')
 * // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
 */
function values(object) {
  return object
    ? (arguments.length > 1)
      ? baseValues(object, flatten(arguments).slice(1))
      : baseValues(object, keys(object))
    : [];
}
```

title: lodashIsPlainObject breaking in Node 0.10
body:
I've been working on releasing a new version of `istanbul-lib-instrument`, so that we can move the babel.js project over to [babel-plugin-istanbul](https://github.com/istanbuljs/babel-plugin-istanbul).

I'm running into an issue with `babel-types` on Node 0.10, which is making tests fail on Node 0.10:

``` bash
istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/babel-types/node_modules/lodash/_setToArray.js:12
  set.forEach(function(value) {
      ^
TypeError: Object #<Set> has no method 'forEach'
    at setToArray (/Users/benjamincoe/bcoe/istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/babel-types/node_modules/lodash/_setToArray.js:12:7)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/benjamincoe/bcoe/istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/babel-types/node_modules/lodash/_createSet.js:15:31)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Module.replacementCompile (/Users/benjamincoe/bcoe/istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/nyc/node_modules/append-transform/index.js:63:13)
    at module.exports (/Users/benjamincoe/bcoe/istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/nyc/node_modules/default-require-extensions/js.js:8:9)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/benjamincoe/bcoe/istanbul-lib-instrument/node_modules/nyc/node_modules/append-transform/index.js:67:4)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:364:17)
    at require (module.js:380:17)
npm ERR! Test failed.  See above for more details.
```

I've tracked the issue down to this set of changes to Lodash:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/compare/4.11.1...4.11.2

CC: @hzoo

title: In lodash/fp, add standard mapping for non-flipped but still autocurried, immutable methods
body:
I often find that I have a need for the non flipped versions as well when doing fp stuff - for example, with `includes` or `get` I often have the case where the part that varies is actually the data. In these cases, I generally add use `_.flip` on the fp functions and have started building a standard mapping for these where it is the method name concatenated with `From` - e.g. `includesFrom = _.flip(_.includes)`, `getFrom = _.flip(_.get)`.

It would be great for this to be part of the core mapping itself as I'm sure I'm not the only one with this common use case. You may want a different convention that `From` as that might conflict with the current convention like `findFrom` - but I think that a solid convention here would be beneficial on non fp lodash as well.

If you don't end up implementing it in fp, I'd still love to get your input on what the convention should be so I can release a small library that just sets up some conversions like fp's convert does.

title: add CDNJS version badge in README.md
body: This will show its version on CDNJS!

title: [q] call a function only once at a time
body:
Hi!

I'm just wondering if there's a lodash function that can make sure "function foo" is only called once at a time?
- if it's called while it is already running, the call is ignored
- if it was called while it was already running, the function will be called with the last parameters

Thanks

title: Feature Request: make the range function work with characters
fp partial right and fp curry
body:
Not sure if this is by design, but it looks like currying something that you've already partially applied fails.

```
const add = (a, b, c) => a + b + c;
const partial = fp.partialRight(add, [5]); // c = 5
cosnt curried = fp.curry(partial);

curried(1, 2); // does not call the function!!!
curried(1, 2, 3); // Calls 1 + 2 + 3
```

It seems that currying stomps over partial application -- is there a good reason for them to not be compatible?

title: Diacritics removal
body:
We were using [node-diacritics](https://github.com/andrewrk/node-diacritics) package. Realized lodash extended its diacritics support. However, it's still not equivalent. 

``` javascript
require('diacritics').remove("Iлｔèｒｎåｔïｏｎɑｌíƶａｔï߀ԉ"))
// prints "Internationalizati0n"
require("lodash").deburr("Iлｔèｒｎåｔïｏｎɑｌíƶａｔï߀ԉ")
// prints "Iлｔeｒｎaｔiｏｎɑｌiƶａｔi߀ԉ"
```

Since we're using lodash anyway, would be perfect if we can drop other dependency. Is there any plan to extend support for other blocks?

title: cloneDeep maintains reference after cloning?
body:
Not sure if this is intended, it doesn't match what I use `_.cloneDeep` for but perhaps it's desired for other cases. It came up unexpectedly in our codebase so I'd be curious—if it's intended behavior—if it could be documented clearly.

It seems that `_.cloneDeep` maintains, in the cloned object, two keys referencing the same object in the original object.

Example case:

``` js
'use strict'

let _ = require('lodash')

let x = { lodash: 'isgreat' }

let y = { 
    one: x,
    two: x,
    three: { 
        javascript: 'isfun' 
    }
}

console.log('One and two are equal in original object?', y.one === y.two)

let yy = _.cloneDeep(y)

console.log('One and two are equal in deep cloned object?', yy.one === yy.two)
console.log('One is different object before and after clone?', y.one === yy.one)
```

This prints:

> One and two are equal in original object? true
> One and two are equal in deep cloned object? true
> One is different object before and after clone? false

I would have expected it to print:

> One and two are equal in original object? true
> One and two are equal in deep cloned object? **false**
> One is different object before and after clone? false

title: Issue "Merge" starting with 4.16.3
Feature request : insertString(string, index, substring)
body:
Hi, it would be nice to have an insertString function :

``` js
/**
 * @param {string} string
 * @param {number} index
 * @param {string} substring
 * @returns {string} New string
 */
export default function insertString(string, index, substring) {
  return [string.slice(0, index), substring, string.slice(index)].join("");
}
```
- There is already a `_.insert` on the road #89
- Underscore.string [have it](http://epeli.github.io/underscore.string/#insert-string-index-substring-gt-string)
- Popularity indicator based [on a SO question](http://stackoverflow.com/q/4364881/1480391)

title: Reduce missing from list of chainable methods?
body:
I noticed that in the Typescript typings, that reduce is not a member of the LoDashExplicitArrayWrapper(i.e., the object returned by_.chain()), and looking at the documentation you don't see `reduce` in the list of chainable methods. But, opening a console right on the lodash.com website and entering the following

`_.chain([1,2,3]).map(x => x * 2).reduce((acc, x) => acc + x).value()`

Returns 12 as one would expect.  Is this a documentation error, or an error in my understanding of what the list of chainable methods is?  I think if this is a chainable method, then adding it to the documentation would also create the support for adding it to the typings as well.

title: ES2015 Iterable protocols not supported?
body:
Hi. Awsome library! It seems that  ES2015 Iterable protocols are not supported? Will this be supported in an upcoming release? It's pretty much  a huge part of the ECMA specs now.

And generators, and the proposed async iteration protocol, what is your thoughts here? Couldn't get it working with your isEqual.

title: _.attempt & _.isError question/proposal
body:
Hello guys,

I was looking at an example that uses `_.attempt` for parsing JSON.
And then uses `_.error` to check if it indeed failed.

The problem with this example is that, if you happen to deserialize an object that happen to have `name` and `message` attributes, it will fail even though the parsing was successful.

What I was wondering is, would it be possible to further differentiate the error object created by `_.attempt` to cover this use case?

For example, do you think that setting a prototype for the error object that includes a property like `type: 'Error'` when creating it with `_.attemp` is a good idea? Then you could also check for that condition in `_.isError` at this line:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.16.4/lodash.js#L11539

The particular example I'm talking about is mentioned in this link: http://colintoh.com/blog/lodash-10-javascript-utility-functions-stop-rewriting#10)_error_handling_for_json.parse

I know it's a very specific case, but I think it'll improve the library as it could be used in a broader number of use cases.

title: Feature: return function from chain when no initial value passed
body:
Here's what I'm proposing:

``` js
> let squareEvens = _()
  .filter(n => n%2 == 0)
  .map(n => n*n)
  .toFunction();
> squareEvens([1, 2, 3, 4]);
[2, 4]
```

title: more date functions
.every function keeps checking values in list after falsey values
body:
The following code:

```
var _ = require('lodash')
a = null
b = [!_.isNil(a), a.b]
```

Produces this error:

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'b' of null
```

I'd expect it to just stop after realising that the first value is `false`.

title: Invalid `exports` entry passed: es & commonjs
body:
In `lodash` / `lodash-cli` version `4.16.4` when I use 

`lodash exports=es` 

I get 

`Invalid `exports` entry passed: es`

Same for `commonjs`

`Invalid `exports` entry passed: commonjs`

either when used alone or independently.

_UPDATE_ Docs say `The exports values “es” & “npm” may only be used in conjunction with the modularize command`, and in fact `modularize` & `es`work (this message could be part of the error meesage). The commonjs is not working with or wihtout `modularize`.

title: Use .nth for .get
body:
Right now this works:

``` js
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], [0])
"foo"
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], [1])
"bar"
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], '0')
"foo"
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], '1')
"bar"
```

There is already an `_.nth`:

``` js
> _.nth(['foo', 'bar'], -1)
"bar"
```

Why shouldn't this work?

``` js
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], [-1])
undefined // expected: 'bar'
> _.get(['foo', 'bar'], '-1')
undefined // possibly also expected: 'bar'
```

title: toBoolean/isBoolean revisted & all-in-one parse
body:
Part in reference to this issue i created before #2065 

Hey @jdalton ,

I know more than likely this is gonna stay a mixin but i wanted to see if you could talk a look and the fiddle and see if thats the best way to do it or is it something you might be interested in for lodash. Any thoughts or critiques would be much appreciated

my use case  has evolved a little now but basically still is the same premises . i need to really take anything the user sends me wether it is a string || boolean || number then i need to parse it for what it is so that i can then use it .for example you will see below the console log the `' TrUe'`. if some user for what ever reason enters that i need to figure out that is should be true(boolean) not just a string.

[JsFiddle Example](https://jsfiddle.net/greenpioneer/4y744xyd/)

EX.

``` Javascript
// parse = 'Green Pioneer'
console.log(_.parse('Green Pioneer'), '- String') 
// parse =  26
console.log(_.parse('26'), '- Number')
// parse = 26
console.log(_.parse(26), '- Number')
// parse = true
console.log(_.parse(true), '- Boolean')
// parse = true
console.log(_.parse('TrUe '), '- Boolean')
```

Check it out let me know

GP

title: Breaking change in _.merge for a patch release (4.16.2 to 4.16.3)?
body:
**4.16.2**

``` javascript
_.merge({}, { a: undefined }); // {}
```

**4.16.3**

``` javascript
_.merge({}, { a: undefined }); // { a: undefined }
```

Is this expected behaviour?

title: lodash.assign deprecated?
body:
After installing the `lodash.assign` package there is a deprecation warning:

```
$ npm install lodash.assign
npm WARN deprecated lodash.assign@4.2.0: This package is deprecated. Use Object.assign.
C:\dev\tmp
`-- lodash.assign@4.2.0
```

Is this by design or is this a mistake?
- The deprecation is not mentioned in the [lodash docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.16.3#assign) nor in the [package's readme](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/4.2.0-npm-packages/lodash.assign).
- The deprecation message suggests using [Object.assign](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/assign), which seems to not be supported in IE, so it can't be used as a replacement yet.

title: [fp] Expose placeholder as a module

More about the problem here - jfmengels/eslint-plugin-lodash-fp#40

title: 4.16.3 Node 4 merge regression
body:
There has been a regression in the `merge` function in lodash version 4.16.3 when using Node 4.

In 4.16.2, running the following code with a file `file.txt` with the contents "hello world" 

```
var _ = require('lodash')
var fs = require('fs')

var fileBuffer = fs.readFileSync('file.txt')

var obj = {
  fileBuffer: fileBuffer
}

var mergedObj = {}

_.merge(mergedObj, obj)

console.log("obj: ")
console.log(obj)

console.log("\n======================\nobj.fileBuffer")
console.log(obj.fileBuffer)

console.log("\n======================\nString(obj.fileBuffer):")
console.log(String(obj.fileBuffer))

console.log("\n======================\nmergedObj:")
console.log(mergedObj)

console.log("\n======================\nmergedObj.fileBuffer")
console.log(mergedObj.fileBuffer)

console.log("\n======================\nString(mergedObj.fileBuffer)")
console.log(String(mergedObj.fileBuffer))
```

will yield the output:

```
obj:
{ fileBuffer: <Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a> }

======================
obj.fileBuffer
<Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a>

======================
String(obj.fileBuffer):
hello world


======================
mergedObj:
{ fileBuffer: <Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a> }

======================
mergedObj.fileBuffer
<Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a>

======================
String(mergedObj.fileBuffer)
hello world
```

4.16.3 yields the same results using Node 6. However, using Node 4, 4.16.3 it will result in the output:

```
obj:
{ fileBuffer: <Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a> }

======================
obj.fileBuffer
<Buffer 68 65 6c 6c 6f 20 77 6f 72 6c 64 0a>

======================
String(obj.fileBuffer):
hello world


======================
mergedObj:
{ fileBuffer: <Buffer 76 61 72 20 5f 20 3d 20 72 65 71 75 69 72 65 28 27 6c 6f 64 61 73 68 27 29 0a 76 61 72 20 66 73 20 3d 20 72 65 71 75 69 72 65 28 27 66 73 27 29 0a 0a ... > }

======================
mergedObj.fileBuffer
<Buffer 76 61 72 20 5f 20 3d 20 72 65 71 75 69 72 65 28 27 6c 6f 64 61 73 68 27 29 0a 76 61 72 20 66 73 20 3d 20 72 65 71 75 69 72 65 28 27 66 73 27 29 0a 0a ... >

======================
String(mergedObj.fileBuffer)
var _ = require('lodash')
var fs = require('fs')

var fileBuffer = fs.readFileSync('file.txt')

var obj = {
  fileBuffer: fileBuffer
}

var mergedObj = {}

_.merge(mergedObj, obj)

console.log("obj: ")
console.log(obj)

console.log("\n======================\nobj.fileBuffer")
console.log(obj.fileBuffer)

console.log("\n======================\nString(obj.fileBuffer):")
console.log(String(obj.fileBuffer))

console.log("\n======================\nmergedObj:")
console.log(mergedObj)

console.log("\n======================\nmergedObj.fileBuffer")
console.log(mergedObj.fileBuffer)

console.log("\n======================\nString(mergedObj.fileBuffer)")
console.log(String(mergedObj.fileBuffer))
hello world
```

title: Migration to ESLint
body:
Since [JSCS is no longer supported](http://eslint.org/blog/2016/04/welcoming-jscs-to-eslint), @jdalton would their be any interest to migrate over to ESLint?

If Yes, then I would be happy to do the work. Wanted to know before doing the work.

title: throttleUntilParamsChange function
Don't drop node 0.10 and 0.12 support
body: Figured I should open an issue about this. As @seldo said on Twitter, it's probably wise to keep supporting 0.10 and 0.12 for around a year.

title: lodash/fp in browser does not handle lodash having been called with `noConflict`
body:
These lines check if `_` is a function, but should really check if it is actually a lodash instance:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/fp/_convertBrowser.js#L15-L17

In our case we still (unfortunately) have some legacy code that needs underscore - we call lodash with noConflict but some code requires underscore to be global. We're working to rip it out completely, but ideally the check here would either be stricter or support some way of opting out of the automatic check (even if it's wrapped in an `if (!window.dontAutoFP)` or something that we can set before the script loads)

title: fp/transform with objects
_.remove doesn't remove falsy values
Lodash migrating guide does not mention absense of _.all method
body:
Hi @jdalton,

I am currently migrating some quite old project from Underscore to Lodash using the migration guide (which is quite awesome, thanks for your work!) from [wiki](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Migrating). 
Currently I am getting type errors stating that `_.all` function is not available and it seems the guide does not say anything about it.
Do you think it's worth mentioning that there is no such method in Lodash and devs should use `_.every` instead?

title: isEmpty() doesn't work with Error objects
body: I'm invoking `_.isEmpty()` on an `Error` object, and it is returning `true`, but I expect it to return `false`. Why is this?

title: On Safari 10, isFunction fails for window.Proxy
What is the recommended way to handle "this" using fp?
body: Some days, you just can't get rid of mutations. In our Knockout ecosystem, there's no getting around mutating `this` without significantly altering our architecture. With core lodash, we'd keep things neat and tidy using `_.extend(this, { .. })`. Since fp doesn't mutate, it doesn't look like we can keep using this pattern without using `convert`.

title: fp docs say partial accepts array of arguments, but it doesn't.
body: It takes a function and an array. Not sure if I'm misreading it, but code may or may not appear to work when transitioning from core lodash depending on whether you are trying to apply strings vs arrays vs functions.

title: fp/map doesn't seem to return an index
throttle(f, 10) calls f 3 times in < 20ms
body:
Is this a bug or is it impossible to be precise with a 10ms wait?

``` js
var throttle = require('lodash.throttle')

var f = throttle(function () {
  console.log('throttled f: ', Date.now())
}, 10)

setTimeout(f, 10)
setTimeout(f, 10)
setTimeout(f, 20)

var g = throttle(function () {
  console.log('throttled g: ', Date.now())
}, 100)

setTimeout(g, 100)
setTimeout(g, 100)
setTimeout(g, 200)
```

Outputs:

```
throttled f:  1475161405424
throttled f:  1475161405427
throttled f:  1475161405438
throttled g:  1475161405500
throttled g:  1475161405602
```

Notice that with the same timing scaled by 10 throttled g gets called one less time.
### Versions

lodash.throttle: `4.1.1`
node: `5.12.0`

Thanks!

title: Differentiating split() from vanilla / proposal for explode()
body:
The _very first time_ I've come across something which is easier in PHP; I have some data elements like this:

```
data-identifier-12345
data-somethingelse-56789
```

and the first part ('data') is the same so I want to remove them. In PHP, this can be done with:

```
explode('-', string, 2)[1]  // Returns ['data', 'identifier-12345'] when limit == 2
```

but I couldn't find a concise JS equivalent. Would lodash consider either an `explode()` function which does the same, or, and I realise this is probably too breaky, to change the behaviour of `split()` to provide that when a limit is specified? I can't currently see the reason you'd use `_.split()` over plain `string.split()` in JS, but perhaps I missed something? Possible code (from [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/19034693/1454454)):

```
_.explode = function(separator, limit)
{
    var arr = this.split(separator);
    if (limit) arr.push( arr.splice(limit-1).join(separator) );
    return arr;
}
```

title: size returns possibly incorrect value for { length: 3 }
body:
If you do `size({ length: 3 })`, it returns `3`. I do sort of get the logic behind this, but in this case, the object was not array like. [Example](https://github.com/jacobp100/recora/commit/9e708a861cae5f0fff4f5872fd9e032eb60d74a1#diff-dfedccebf267017bb1670428731d926dR52)

Either this should be documented, or the logic might need changing.

title: How to access templateSettings when using module build of lodash.template?
Are lodash/fp aliases stable?
body: Will aliases (e.g `_.contains`) be supported in perpetuity?

title: Union fails on empty arrays?
body:
I'm not sure if this is expected behavior or not but using `lodash.union` `^4.6.0` if you call it with:

``` js
union([ [] ]);
```

It returns the original array `[ [] ]`. The same thing happens with multiple empty arrays as sub-arrays.

Is this expected? I was expecting it simply return `[]`.

title: Impossible to print lodash docs
remove() is not in version 4.16.2 yet it is listed in the documentation
body:
The docs of 4.16.2 (https://lodash.com/docs/4.16.2) list a remove() function that is nowhere to be found in the core distributable file https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lodash/lodash/4.16.2/dist/lodash.core.js

The same applies to 4.16.1.

title: Change _.fromPairs() to specify key and value from array of objects
defaultsDeep with different results for undefined properties
body:
Using `defaultsDeep`, `undefined` properties get filtered out when they're in the root level of the object, but not when they're nested. If `defaultsDeep` is meant to act recursively, shouldn't its rules be the same regardless of the nesting level?

To reproduce this issue:

``` js
> _.defaultsDeep({}, { foo: undefined })
{}

> _.defaultsDeep({}, { bar: { foo: undefined } })
{ bar: { foo: undefined } }  // by the same rules, shouldn't it be `{ bar: {} }` ?
```

title: API proposal for _.replaceAll
Lodash 4.16.1 slowed some methods

I did not conduct a comparison of all methods.
But the example `_.sampleSize` seen a noticeable drop in performance.

title: extend own enumerable string keyed properties of target?
body:
Hi,

Is there any function to achieve the following?

```
_.func(object, [sources])
_.func({ 'a':1, 'b':2 },{ 'a':4,'c':5 })
// => { 'a': 4, 'b': 2 }
```

I only want to get new value if the destination object has that key, ignoring any new keys from sources.

Thanks

title: Throttle by execution count
body: Would there be any interest in a throttle method that invokes after a number of executions rather than after an amount of time has passed? I wrote up a proof of concept of such a method [here](https://gist.github.com/cbargren/3ab3e79b65fc953e805ff8c598fddd95).

title: Problem With findIndex and partial-ed startsWith
body:
When I use a `partial`-ed `startsWith` with `findIndex` I get a different result from the equivalent arrow function.  In other words, if I do:

```
const v1StartsWith = _.partial(_.startsWith, _, 'baz');
const v2StartsWith = (x) => _.startsWith(x, 'baz');

v1StartsWith('foobar'); // false
v2StartsWith('foobar'); // false

v1StartsWith('bazqux'); // true
v2StartsWith('bazqux'); // true
```

So far so good, but when we use `_.findIndex` ...

```
_.findIndex(['foobar', 'bazqux'], v1StartsWith); // -1
_.findIndex(['foobar', 'bazqux'], v2StartsWith); // 1
```

Since both versions return `true`, it seems like `_.findIndex` should return `1` both times, but for some reason that's not the case with the `partial`-ed version.

when there should be a more pojo means of testing, such as 
`typeof (fooprop) === 'undefined'`

title: Include lodash for testing in browser's console when viewing documentation
body:
Dear Lodash Developers,

Before your most recent update, our team of engineers and I would test out lodash functions while viewing documentation through the console. This was very not only convenient for us but it also drove up the usage of your website.

We are no longer able to do so with the latest update.

Can you please include lodash in a place that we are able to access it and test out your functions in the browser's console?

Thank you!

Best,
Chris

title: Using ES6 template delimiters with _.template to evaluate expression
body:
Current implementation of _.template with ES6's style of template delimiters don't work as expected, they don't evaluate expressions. 

The following will fail:

```
_.template('hello ${ user() }')({user: () => 'marcel'})

```

I can of course set the reEsTemplate manually, but not reference it:

```
_.template('hello ${ user() }', { evaluate: /\$\{([^\\}]*(?:\\.[^\\}]*)*)\}/g } );
```

I understand the reasoning behind not exposing it in _.templateSettings, so that's why I'm asking what's a good place to expose the [reEsTemplate](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.15.0/lodash.js#L162) pattern so we can reuse it without copying from source.

title: Is there a Lodash Function which will mask the values of provided keys ?
body:
We log our payloads so we want to mask the keys of PII and PCI related information, like SSN/PIN and so forth...

I came up with JSON.stringify solution, but wasn't able to find something like _.mask(object/array,['pin','ssn'], *)..

May be there might be a solution available combining multiple methods  ? 

Thanks,
Sameer

title: Do you have plan to make sortBy() and orderBy() lazy?
body:
We note that ds.sortBy().slice(start, end) and ds.orderBy().slice(start, end) can be calculated effectively on large data set, which time cost is O(n), not O(nln(n)).

Using algorithm like quick sort. Please read : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_algorithm#Partial_selection_sort

Step 1. find the start-th, end-th smallest element; (which is O(n))
Step 2. find all element between the two elements; (also O(n))

So, Do you have plan to make sortBy() and orderBy() lazy and more effectively?
Or Do you have any other good suggestions?

Thanks!

title: _.isDefined (Duplicate/Resurrected Issue)
body:
First off, I'm aware that this was originally closed in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/137.  I'm resurrecting it because I felt neither that issue nor it's multiple duplicates gives a strong justification of why `_.isDefined` adds value to the library (so I figured I'd give it a shot).

Basically what it all boils down to is your 5th grade English class: double-negatives ("nobody can not ignore") are prohibited in English.  Why?  They make your brain work harder, for no good reason: "everyone can ignore" means the same thing as "nobody can not ignore", but the latter requires more brain cycles.

What does that have to do with code?  Well, programmers' as a group would almost universally agree that:

```
if (!(foo === 'bar')) // who does this?

if (foo !== 'bar') // everyone does this
```

Now, consider that `isUndefined` is very often used as follows:

```
if (!_.isUndefined(foo)) {
    doSomething(foo);
}
```

Myself, the people who filed the duplicates, the people who thumbs-upped the original ticket (that's a lot of people who took time to support something so trivial!) ... we all feel that the above code is like `!(foo === 'bar')`, and we wish to use the `foo !== 'bar'` equivalent:

```
if (_.isDefined(foo)) { ...
```

Now, to be fair, it's not a massive cognitive load to mentally translate the former in the latter.  But when given:

```
if (!_.isUndefined(foo)) { .. // vs.
if (_.isDefined(foo)) { ...
```

I think the vast majority of programmers would agree the latter is easier read/process.

Lodash is an entire library made up of small conveniences which make developers' lives easier and their code cleaner and easier to understand. It seems to me that  `_.isDefined` fits that criteria perfectly.

P.S. To our BDFL JDalton's point:

> I'm not a fan of _.isUndefined to begin with

I would argue that it's all about `0` (although sometimes also about other "falsy" values too).  When you have a function which can possibly take a `0`, but which wants to invalidate other "falsy" values (a fairly common occurrence, at least in my experience), there's no better/cleaner way to do so than `_.isUndefined`:

```
function(foo) {
   if (!foo && foo !=== 0) // lame
   if (_.isUndefined(foo)) // awesome (especially if foo has a longer name)
```

Or, if other "falsy" values are allowed:

```
   if (!foo && foo !=== 0 && foo !=== false && foo !== '') // really lame
   if (_.isUndefined(foo)) // even more awesome
```

```
_.lowerCase('HELLOworld')
```

yields


Expected

```

```

title: coveralls@2.11.13 untested ⚠️

Hello lovely humans, [coveralls](https://www.npmjs.com/package/coveralls) just published its new version 2.11.13.
State No tests :warning:
Dependency coveralls
New version 2.11.13
Type devDependency
This version is **covered** by your **current version range**, but I **could not detect automated tests** for this project. Without a test suite I **can not really tell whether your project still works**. I was looking at the latest commit of your default branch, but GitHub said there is no status attached to it. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn’t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work?
